content: Good afternoon, Jason Clarke. Welcome to your AI interview for the SDR role. Can you hear me clearly?
Great. Let's start off simple—can you briefly introduce yourself and share why you're interested in this SDR position?

Sure! I’m Jason, I’ve worked in customer-facing roles for the past three years, most recently in a lead generation agency. I’m drawn to SDR work because I enjoy building rapport quickly and love the challenge of turning cold leads into warm opportunities.
Thanks for that. In your view, what makes a cold outreach message effective?

Relevance and personalization. You have to show that you’ve done your research—mention something specific to them or their company, and then connect it to a value prop that actually matters to their role.
Can you give an example of how you handled rejection from a prospect?

Definitely. I once reached out to a VP of Marketing who replied with a very blunt 'not interested.' I followed up a few weeks later with a case study relevant to their industry and kept it super short. A week after that, they booked a call. Sometimes it’s just about timing and staying respectful.
Nice follow-up. How do you prioritize your leads and manage your outreach pipeline?

I segment my leads by industry and title, then score them based on engagement signals—like email opens or LinkedIn views. I use a cadence tool to automate touches, but I always personalize the first one. And I block time every day to review replies and adjust my messaging.
Good system. Last question: what motivates you in a sales role, especially when things are tough?
I’m really driven by goals and progress. I actually enjoy the grind of it—tracking my numbers, experimenting with messaging, and learning from the nos. The challenge is part of what keeps me engaged.
Thank you, Jason. That wraps up your AI interview. You’ll hear back soon regarding next steps.
